About me

I've done lots of different things with my time, but it all leads to intentionally designed clarity and communication, especially around science and data. It all makes sense.

Close
Contact

Footsteps in the sands of time

Highschool yearbook editor baby! And so the journey to layout, technology and communication begins...

Maps and deserts

I went to the University of Arizona and worked at the Arizona Remote Sensing Center. We made online mapping tools to aid land management and ran outreach programs to help non-techies use them (aka, Geospatial Extension).

Alternative A, B or C?

I worked as an environmental planner at the URS Corporation. We analyzed environmental decision alternatives and helped people understand what this would mean for them.

It's the learning environment

My graduate work is in Chinese environmental policy (ask me about Xinjiang and Inner Mongolia drylands management sometime). A great way to practice conveying information succinctly yet clearly is by learning another language! 我也会讲普通话 ^_^

Satellites and seagulls

Science communication was the name of the game at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Satellite and Information Service. Here, I worked on international and interagency data sharing as well as general digital communications strategy.

Innovation and bisons

I'm currently a Presidential Innovation Fellow at the Department of the Interior working on making public data more accessible and understandable.

That's me!

About This Site

Behind the curtain My site is powered by Jekyll, a Ruby-based site generator that uses Liquid as its templating language. It is hosted entirely on GitHub (thanks to Kin Lane and his Hacker Storytelling for the technique!).

On stage My design was built on top of Skeleton, a bare-bones responsive framework. Fonts are Bree from Type Together, and Freight Sans from Darden Studio.
